snippet: European countries remained divided and confused over how to handle the situation as an Austrian official called on Germany to clarify its asylum rules.
abstract: Keleti train station in Budapest cuts off service to migrants as crisis escalates and European nations remain bitterly divided over to handle arrival of tens of thousands of migrants, battered by civil war and conflict in the Middle East and Syria.

byline.original: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS and DAN BILEFSKY
byline.contributor: Anemona Hartocollis reported from Budapest, and Dan Bilefsky from London. Palko Karasz contributed reporting from Budapest, Alison Smale from Vienna, and Melissa Eddy from Berlin.

lead_paragraph: European countries remained divided and confused over how to handle the situation as an Austrian official called on Germany to clarify its asylum rules.

headline.main: Train Station in Budapest Cuts Off Service to Migrants
headline.print_headline: Train Station in Budapest Cuts Off Service to Migrants

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
